content.question: The following questions refer to this passage: Vitas inuleo1 me similis, Chloe, quaerenti pavidam montibus aviis matrem non sine vano aurarum et silvae metu. (5) Nam seu mobilibus veris* inhorruit adventus foliis, seu virides rubum dimovere lacertae, et corde et genibus tremit. Atqui non ego te tigris ut aspera (10) Gaetulusve leo frangere persequor: tandem desine matrem tempestiva sequi viro. 1inuleus, -i, m. (also spelled hinnuleus in some texts): fawn *also appears as vepris in some texts In the poem above, Horace uses animal imagery to characterize human relationships. In a short essay, explain how this imagery is developed throughout the poem. Refer specifically to the Latin to support your answer.

unit.text: 4: Teacher's Choice - Latin Poetry and Vergil's Aeneid, Excerpts from Books 1 and 2

skill.text: 3.A: Develop an interpretation of a Latin text.
